trans-unit.source: Submit Hive Queries to Hadoop clusters in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive Queries to Hadoop clusters in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Process Data from Hive Tables with Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: Process Data from Hive Tables with Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive Queries to HDInsight Hadoop clusters in the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology

trans-unit.source: This document describes various ways of submitting Hive queries to Hadoop clusters that are managed by an HDInsight service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This document describes various ways of submitting Hive queries to Hadoop clusters that are managed by an HDInsight service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This task is part of the Cortana Analytics Process (CAP).
trans-unit.target: This task is part of the Cortana Analytics Process (CAP).

trans-unit.source: Several data wrangling tasks are discussed: data exploration and feature generation.
trans-unit.target: Several data wrangling tasks are discussed: data exploration and feature generation.

trans-unit.source: Generic Hive queries that show how to explore data or generate features using Hive in an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster are presented.
trans-unit.target: Generic Hive queries that show how to explore data or generate features using Hive in an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster are presented.

trans-unit.source: These Hive queries use embedded Hive User Defined Functions (UDFs) which are provided.
trans-unit.target: These Hive queries use embedded Hive User Defined Functions (UDFs) which are provided.

trans-unit.source: Examples of queries that are specific to [NYC Taxi Trip Data](http://chriswhong.com/open-data/foil_nyc_taxi/) scenarios are also provided in [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts).
trans-unit.target: Examples of queries that are specific to [NYC Taxi Trip Data](http://chriswhong.com/open-data/foil_nyc_taxi/) scenarios are also provided in [Github repository](https://github.com/Azure/Azure-MachineLearning-DataScience/tree/master/Misc/DataScienceProcess/DataScienceScripts).

trans-unit.source: These queries already have data schema specified and are ready to be submitted to run.
trans-unit.target: These queries already have data schema specified and are ready to be submitted to run.

trans-unit.source: In the final section, parameters that can be used to tune and improve the performance of Hive queries are discussed.
trans-unit.target: In the final section, parameters that can be used to tune and improve the performance of Hive queries are discussed.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: This article assumes that you have:
trans-unit.target: This article assumes that you have:

trans-unit.source: Created an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Created an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see [Create an Azure Storage account](../hdinsight-get-started.md#storage)
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see [Create an Azure Storage account](../hdinsight-get-started.md#storage)

trans-unit.source: Provisioned a customized Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.
trans-unit.target: Provisioned a customized Hadoop cluster with the HDInsight service.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see [Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters for Advanced Analytics](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md).
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see [Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters for Advanced Analytics](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md).

trans-unit.source: The data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.
trans-unit.target: The data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.

trans-unit.source: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-move-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.
trans-unit.target: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-move-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.

trans-unit.source: Enabled remote access to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Enabled remote access to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you need instructions, see [Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md#headnode).
trans-unit.target: If you need instructions, see [Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster](machine-learning-data-science-customize-hadoop-cluster.md#headnode).

trans-unit.source: How to Submit Hive Queries
trans-unit.target: How to Submit Hive Queries

trans-unit.source: Hive queries can be submitted by using the following applications:
trans-unit.target: Hive queries can be submitted by using the following applications:

trans-unit.source: **Hadoop Command Line console** on the headnode of the cluster
trans-unit.target: **Hadoop Command Line console** on the headnode of the cluster

trans-unit.source: **IPython Notebook**
trans-unit.target: **IPython Notebook**

trans-unit.source: **Hive Editor**
trans-unit.target: **Hive Editor**

trans-unit.source: **PowerShell** scripts
trans-unit.target: **PowerShell** scripts

trans-unit.source: Hive queries are SQL-like.
trans-unit.target: Hive queries are SQL-like.

trans-unit.source: Users familiar with SQL may find the
trans-unit.target: Users familiar with SQL may find the

trans-unit.source: SQL-to-Hive Cheat Sheet
trans-unit.target: SQL-to-Hive Cheat Sheet

trans-unit.source: useful.
trans-unit.target: useful.

trans-unit.source: When submitting a Hive query, you can also control the destination of the output from Hive queries, whether it be on the screen or to a local file on the head node or to an Azure blob.
trans-unit.target: When submitting a Hive query, you can also control the destination of the output from Hive queries, whether it be on the screen or to a local file on the head node or to an Azure blob.

trans-unit.source: Through Hadoop Command Line console in Head Node of Hadoop Cluster
trans-unit.target: Through Hadoop Command Line console in Head Node of Hadoop Cluster

trans-unit.source: If the query is complex, submitting Hive queries directly from the head node of the Hadoop cluster typically leads to faster turn around than submitting it with a Hive Editor or by using Azure PowerShell scripts.
trans-unit.target: If the query is complex, submitting Hive queries directly from the head node of the Hadoop cluster typically leads to faster turn around than submitting it with a Hive Editor or by using Azure PowerShell scripts.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line on the desktop of the head node, and enter command
trans-unit.target: Log in to the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the Hadoop Command Line on the desktop of the head node, and enter command

trans-unit.source: Users have three ways to submit Hive queries in Hadoop Command Line console:
trans-unit.target: Users have three ways to submit Hive queries in Hadoop Command Line console:

trans-unit.source: directly from the Hadoop command line
trans-unit.target: directly from the Hadoop command line

trans-unit.source: using .hql files
trans-unit.target: using .hql files

trans-unit.source: from the Hive command console
trans-unit.target: from the Hive command console

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries directly from the Hadoop Command Line
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries directly from the Hadoop Command Line

trans-unit.target: Users can run command like

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries in .hql files
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries in .hql files

trans-unit.source: When the Hive query is more complicated and has multiple lines, editing queries in Hadoop command line or Hive command console is not practical.
trans-unit.target: When the Hive query is more complicated and has multiple lines, editing queries in Hadoop command line or Hive command console is not practical.

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to use a text editor in the head node of the Hadoop cluster and to save the Hive queries in a .hql file in a local directory of the head node.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to use a text editor in the head node of the Hadoop cluster and to save the Hive queries in a .hql file in a local directory of the head node.

trans-unit.source: Then the Hive query in the .hql file can be submitted by using the `-f` argument in the `hive` command as follows:
trans-unit.target: Then the Hive query in the .hql file can be submitted by using the `-f` argument in the `hive` command as follows:

trans-unit.source: Suppress progress status screen print of Hive queries
trans-unit.target: Suppress progress status screen print of Hive queries

trans-unit.source: By default, after Hive query is submitted in the Hadoop Command Line console, the progress of the Map/Reduce job will be printed out on screen.
trans-unit.target: By default, after Hive query is submitted in the Hadoop Command Line console, the progress of the Map/Reduce job will be printed out on screen.

trans-unit.source: To suppress the screen print of the Map/Reduce job progress, you can use the argument `-S` (case-sensitive) argument in the command line as follows:
trans-unit.target: To suppress the screen print of the Map/Reduce job progress, you can use the argument `-S` (case-sensitive) argument in the command line as follows:

trans-unit.source: Submit Hive queries in Hive command console.
trans-unit.target: Submit Hive queries in Hive command console.

trans-unit.source: Users can also enter the Hive command console by running the `hive` command from the Hadoop command line, and then submit Hive queries from Hive command console at the **hive>** prompt.
trans-unit.target: Users can also enter the Hive command console by running the `hive` command from the Hadoop command line, and then submit Hive queries from Hive command console at the **hive>** prompt.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example.
trans-unit.target: Here is an example.

trans-unit.target: In this example, the two red boxes highlight the commands used to enter the Hive command console, and the Hive query submitted in Hive command console, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The green box highlights the output from the Hive query.
trans-unit.target: The green box highlights the output from the Hive query.

trans-unit.source: The previous examples directly output the Hive query results on screen.
trans-unit.target: The previous examples directly output the Hive query results on screen.

trans-unit.source: Users can also write the output to a local file on the head node, or to an Azure blob.
trans-unit.target: Users can also write the output to a local file on the head node, or to an Azure blob.

trans-unit.source: Then, users can use other tools to further analyze the output of from Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: Then, users can use other tools to further analyze the output of from Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Output Hive query results to a local file.
trans-unit.target: Output Hive query results to a local file.

trans-unit.source: To output Hive query results to a local directory on the head node, users have to submit the Hive query in the Hadoop Command Line as follows:
trans-unit.target: To output Hive query results to a local directory on the head node, users have to submit the Hive query in the Hadoop Command Line as follows:

trans-unit.source: Output Hive query results to an Azure blob
trans-unit.target: Output Hive query results to an Azure blob

trans-unit.source: Users can also output the Hive query results to an Azure blob, within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Users can also output the Hive query results to an Azure blob, within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: The Hive query to do this looks like this:
trans-unit.target: The Hive query to do this looks like this:

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the output of Hive query is written to a blob directory `queryoutputdir` within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the output of Hive query is written to a blob directory `queryoutputdir` within the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: Here, you must only provide the directory name, without the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Here, you must only provide the directory name, without the blob name.

trans-unit.source: An error will be thrown out if you provide both the directory and the blob name, such as *wasb:///queryoutputdir/queryoutput.txt*.
trans-unit.target: An error will be thrown out if you provide both the directory and the blob name, such as *wasb:///queryoutputdir/queryoutput.txt*.

trans-unit.source: ![Create workspace](./media/machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables/output-hive-results-2.png)
trans-unit.target: ![Create workspace](./media/machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables/output-hive-results-2.png)

trans-unit.source: The output of the Hive query can be seen in blob storage by opening the default container of the Hadoop cluster using the Azure Storage Explorer (or equivalent) tool.
trans-unit.target: The output of the Hive query can be seen in blob storage by opening the default container of the Hadoop cluster using the Azure Storage Explorer (or equivalent) tool.

trans-unit.source: You can apply the filter (highlighted by red box) if you only want to retrieve a blob with specified letters in names.
trans-unit.target: You can apply the filter (highlighted by red box) if you only want to retrieve a blob with specified letters in names.

trans-unit.target: ![Create workspace](./media/machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables/output-hive-results-3.png)

trans-unit.source: Through Hive Editor or Azure PowerShell Commands
trans-unit.target: Through Hive Editor or Azure PowerShell Commands

trans-unit.source: Users can also use the Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL of the form
trans-unit.target: Users can also use the Query Console (Hive Editor) by entering the URL of the form

trans-unit.source: *https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor*
trans-unit.target: *https://<Hadoop cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net/Home/HiveEditor*

trans-unit.source: into a web browser.
trans-unit.target: into a web browser.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will be asked to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will be asked to input the Hadoop cluster credentials to log in.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can [Submit Hive jobs using PowerShell](../hdinsight/hdinsight-submit-hadoop-jobs-programmatically.md#hive-powershell).
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can [Submit Hive jobs using PowerShell](../hdinsight/hdinsight-submit-hadoop-jobs-programmatically.md#hive-powershell).

trans-unit.source: Data Exploration
trans-unit.target: Data Exploration

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample Hive scripts that can be used to explore data in Hive tables.
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample Hive scripts that can be used to explore data in Hive tables.

trans-unit.source: Get the count of observations per partition `SELECT <partitionfieldname>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <partitionfieldname>;`
trans-unit.target: Get the count of observations per partition `SELECT <partitionfieldname>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <partitionfieldname>;`

trans-unit.source: Get the count of observations per day `SELECT to_date(<date_columnname>), count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by to_date(<date_columnname>);`
trans-unit.target: Get the count of observations per day `SELECT to_date(<date_columnname>), count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by to_date(<date_columnname>);`

trans-unit.source: Get the levels in a categorical column `SELECT distinct <column_name> from <databasename>.<tablename>`
trans-unit.target: Get the levels in a categorical column `SELECT distinct <column_name> from <databasename>.<tablename>`

trans-unit.source: Get the number of levels in combination of two categorical columns `SELECT <column_a>, <column_b>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <column_a>, <column_b>`
trans-unit.target: Get the number of levels in combination of two categorical columns `SELECT <column_a>, <column_b>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <column_a>, <column_b>`

trans-unit.source: Get the distribution for numerical columns `SELECT <column_name>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <column_name>`
trans-unit.target: Get the distribution for numerical columns `SELECT <column_name>, count(*) from <databasename>.<tablename> group by <column_name>`

trans-unit.source: Extract records from joining two tables
trans-unit.target: Extract records from joining two tables

trans-unit.source: Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we describe ways of generating features using Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The sample Hive queries in this section assumes that the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The sample Hive queries in this section assumes that the data has been uploaded to Hive tables in Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters.

trans-unit.source: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.
trans-unit.target: If it has not, please follow [Create and load data to Hive tables](machine-learning-data-science-hive-tables.md) to upload data to Hive tables first.

trans-unit.source: Once you have generated additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, which can then be joined with the original table.
trans-unit.target: Once you have generated additional features, you can either add them as columns to the existing table or create a new table with the additional features and primary key, which can then be joined with the original table.

trans-unit.source: [Frequency based Feature Generation](#hive-frequencyfeature)
trans-unit.target: [Frequency based Feature Generation](#hive-frequencyfeature)

trans-unit.source: [Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification](#hive-riskfeature)
trans-unit.target: [Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification](#hive-riskfeature)

trans-unit.source: [Extract features from Datetime Field](#hive-datefeatures)
trans-unit.target: [Extract features from Datetime Field](#hive-datefeatures)

trans-unit.source: [Extract features from Text Field](#hive-textfeatures)
trans-unit.target: [Extract features from Text Field](#hive-textfeatures)

trans-unit.source: [Calculate distance between GPS coordinates](#hive-gpsdistance)
trans-unit.target: [Calculate distance between GPS coordinates](#hive-gpsdistance)

trans-unit.source: Frequency based Feature Generation
trans-unit.target: Frequency based Feature Generation

trans-unit.source: It is often useful to calculate the frequencies of the levels of a categorical variable, or the frequencies of certain combinations of levels from multiple categorical variables.
trans-unit.target: It is often useful to calculate the frequencies of the levels of a categorical variable, or the frequencies of certain combinations of levels from multiple categorical variables.

trans-unit.source: Users can use the following script to calculate these frequencies:
trans-unit.target: Users can use the following script to calculate these frequencies:

trans-unit.source: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification
trans-unit.target: Risks of Categorical Variables in Binary Classification

trans-unit.source: In binary classification, we need to convert non-numeric categorical variables into numeric features when the models being used only take numeric features.
trans-unit.target: In binary classification, we need to convert non-numeric categorical variables into numeric features when the models being used only take numeric features.

trans-unit.source: This is done by replacing each non-numeric level with a numeric risk.
trans-unit.target: This is done by replacing each non-numeric level with a numeric risk.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we show some generic Hive queries that calculate the risk values (log odds) of a categorical variable.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we show some generic Hive queries that calculate the risk values (log odds) of a categorical variable.

trans-unit.source: In this example, variables `smooth_param1` and `smooth_param2` are set to smooth the risk values calculated from the data. Ri
trans-unit.target: In this example, variables `smooth_param1` and `smooth_param2` are set to smooth the risk values calculated from the data. Ri

trans-unit.source: sks have a range between -Inf and Inf. A
trans-unit.target: sks have a range between -Inf and Inf. A

trans-unit.source: risks > 0 indicates that the probability that the target is equal to 1 is greater than 0.5.
trans-unit.target: risks > 0 indicates that the probability that the target is equal to 1 is greater than 0.5.

trans-unit.source: After the risk table is calculated, users can assign risk values to a table by joining it with the risk table.
trans-unit.target: After the risk table is calculated, users can assign risk values to a table by joining it with the risk table.

trans-unit.source: The Hive joining query was provided in previous section.
trans-unit.target: The Hive joining query was provided in previous section.

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Datetime Fields
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Datetime Fields

trans-unit.source: Hive comes with a set of UDFs for processing datetime fields.
trans-unit.target: Hive comes with a set of UDFs for processing datetime fields.

trans-unit.source: In Hive, the default datetime format is 'yyyy-MM-dd 00:00:00' ('1970-01-01 12:21:32' for example).
trans-unit.target: In Hive, the default datetime format is 'yyyy-MM-dd 00:00:00' ('1970-01-01 12:21:32' for example).

trans-unit.source: In this section, we show examples that extract the day of a month, the month from a datetime field, and other examples that convert a datetime string in a format other than the default format to a datetime string in default format.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we show examples that extract the day of a month, the month from a datetime field, and other examples that convert a datetime string in a format other than the default format to a datetime string in default format.

trans-unit.source: This Hive query assumes that the *<datetime field>* is in the default datetime format.
trans-unit.target: This Hive query assumes that the *<datetime field>* is in the default datetime format.

trans-unit.source: If a datetime field is not in the default format, you need to convert the datetime field into Unix time stamp first, and then convert the Unix time stamp to a datetime string that is in the default format.
trans-unit.target: If a datetime field is not in the default format, you need to convert the datetime field into Unix time stamp first, and then convert the Unix time stamp to a datetime string that is in the default format.

trans-unit.source: When the datetime is in default format, users can apply the embedded datetime UDFs to extract features.
trans-unit.target: When the datetime is in default format, users can apply the embedded datetime UDFs to extract features.

trans-unit.source: In this query, if the *<datetime field>* has the pattern like *03/26/2015 12:04:39*, the *'<pattern of the datetime field>'* should be `'MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss'`.
trans-unit.target: In this query, if the *<datetime field>* has the pattern like *03/26/2015 12:04:39*, the *'<pattern of the datetime field>'* should be `'MM/dd/yyyy HH:mm:ss'`.

trans-unit.source: To test it, users can run
trans-unit.target: To test it, users can run

trans-unit.source: The *hivesampletable* in this query comes preinstalled on all Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters by default when the clusters are provisioned.
trans-unit.target: The *hivesampletable* in this query comes preinstalled on all Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters by default when the clusters are provisioned.

trans-unit.source: Extract features from Text Fields
trans-unit.target: Extract features from Text Fields

trans-unit.source: When the Hive table has a text field that contains a string of words that are delimited by spaces, the following query extracts the length of the string, and the number of words in the string.
trans-unit.target: When the Hive table has a text field that contains a string of words that are delimited by spaces, the following query extracts the length of the string, and the number of words in the string.

trans-unit.source: Calculate distances between sets of GPS coordinates
trans-unit.target: Calculate distances between sets of GPS coordinates

trans-unit.source: The query given in this section can be directly applied to the NYC Taxi Trip Data.
trans-unit.target: The query given in this section can be directly applied to the NYC Taxi Trip Data.

trans-unit.source: The purpose of this query is to show how to apply an embedded mathematical functions in Hive to generate features.
trans-unit.target: The purpose of this query is to show how to apply an embedded mathematical functions in Hive to generate features.

trans-unit.source: The fields that are used in this query are the GPS coordinates of pickup and dropoff locations, named *pickup\_longitude*, *pickup\_latitude*, *dropoff\_longitude*, and *dropoff\_latitude*.
trans-unit.target: The fields that are used in this query are the GPS coordinates of pickup and dropoff locations, named *pickup\_longitude*, *pickup\_latitude*, *dropoff\_longitude*, and *dropoff\_latitude*.

trans-unit.source: The queries that calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff coordinates are:
trans-unit.target: The queries that calculate the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff coordinates are:

trans-unit.source: The mathematical equations that calculate the distance between two GPS coordinates can be found on the Movable Type Scripts site, authored by Peter Lapisu.
trans-unit.target: The mathematical equations that calculate the distance between two GPS coordinates can be found on the Movable Type Scripts site, authored by Peter Lapisu.

trans-unit.source: In his Javascript, the function `toRad()` is just *lat_or_lon*pi/180*, which converts degrees to radians.
trans-unit.target: In his Javascript, the function `toRad()` is just *lat_or_lon*pi/180*, which converts degrees to radians.

trans-unit.source: Here, *lat_or_lon* is the latitude or longitude.
trans-unit.target: Here, *lat_or_lon* is the latitude or longitude.

trans-unit.source: Since Hive does not provide the function `atan2`, but provides the function `atan`, the `atan2` function is implemented by `atan` function in the above Hive query using the definition provided in Wikipedia.
trans-unit.target: Since Hive does not provide the function `atan2`, but provides the function `atan`, the `atan2` function is implemented by `atan` function in the above Hive query using the definition provided in Wikipedia.

trans-unit.source: ![test](./media/machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables/atan2new.png)
trans-unit.target: ![test](./media/machine-learning-data-science-process-hive-tables/atan2new.png)

trans-unit.source: A full list of Hive embedded UDFs can be found in the **Built-in Functions** section on the Apache Hive wiki).
trans-unit.target: A full list of Hive embedded UDFs can be found in the **Built-in Functions** section on the Apache Hive wiki).

trans-unit.source: Advanced topics: Tune Hive Parameters to Improve Query Speed
trans-unit.target: Advanced topics: Tune Hive Parameters to Improve Query Speed

trans-unit.source: The default parameter settings of Hive cluster might not be suitable for the Hive queries and the data that the queries are processing.
trans-unit.target: The default parameter settings of Hive cluster might not be suitable for the Hive queries and the data that the queries are processing.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we discuss some parameters that users can tune that improve the performance of Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we discuss some parameters that users can tune that improve the performance of Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Users need to add the parameter tuning queries before the queries of processing data.
trans-unit.target: Users need to add the parameter tuning queries before the queries of processing data.

trans-unit.source: **Java heap space**: For queries involving joining large datasets, or processing long records, **running out of heap space** is one of the common error.
trans-unit.target: **Java heap space**: For queries involving joining large datasets, or processing long records, **running out of heap space** is one of the common error.

trans-unit.source: This can be tuned by setting parameters *mapreduce.map.java.opts* and *mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb* to desired values.
trans-unit.target: This can be tuned by setting parameters *mapreduce.map.java.opts* and *mapreduce.task.io.sort.mb* to desired values.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example:

trans-unit.source: This parameter allocates 4GB memory to Java heap space and also makes sorting more efficient by allocating more memory for it.
trans-unit.target: This parameter allocates 4GB memory to Java heap space and also makes sorting more efficient by allocating more memory for it.

trans-unit.source: It is a good idea to play with these allocations if there are any job failure errors related to heap space.
trans-unit.target: It is a good idea to play with these allocations if there are any job failure errors related to heap space.

trans-unit.source: **DFS block size** : This parameter sets the smallest unit of data that the file system stores.
trans-unit.target: **DFS block size** : This parameter sets the smallest unit of data that the file system stores.

trans-unit.source: As an example, if the DFS block size is 128MB, then any data of size less than and up to 128MB is stored in a single block, while data that is larger than 128MB is allotted extra blocks.
trans-unit.target: As an example, if the DFS block size is 128MB, then any data of size less than and up to 128MB is stored in a single block, while data that is larger than 128MB is allotted extra blocks.

trans-unit.source: Choosing a very small block size causes large overheads in Hadoop since the name node has to process many more requests to find the relevant block pertaining to the file.
trans-unit.target: Choosing a very small block size causes large overheads in Hadoop since the name node has to process many more requests to find the relevant block pertaining to the file.

trans-unit.source: A recommended setting when dealing with gigabytes (or larger) data is :
trans-unit.target: A recommended setting when dealing with gigabytes (or larger) data is :

trans-unit.source: **Optimizing join operation in Hive** : While join operations in the map/reduce framework typically take place in the reduce phase, sometimes, enormous gains can be achieved by scheduling joins in the map phase (also called "mapjoins").
trans-unit.target: **Optimizing join operation in Hive** : While join operations in the map/reduce framework typically take place in the reduce phase, sometimes, enormous gains can be achieved by scheduling joins in the map phase (also called "mapjoins").

trans-unit.source: To direct Hive to do this whenever possible, we can set :
trans-unit.target: To direct Hive to do this whenever possible, we can set :

trans-unit.source: **Specifying the number of mappers to Hive** : While Hadoop allows the user to set the number of reducers, the number of mappers is typically not be set by the user.
trans-unit.target: **Specifying the number of mappers to Hive** : While Hadoop allows the user to set the number of reducers, the number of mappers is typically not be set by the user.

trans-unit.source: A trick that allows some degree of control on this number is to choose the Hadoop variables, *mapred.min.split.size* and *mapred.max.split.size* as the size of each map task is determined by :
trans-unit.target: A trick that allows some degree of control on this number is to choose the Hadoop variables, *mapred.min.split.size* and *mapred.max.split.size* as the size of each map task is determined by :

trans-unit.source: Typically, the default value of *mapred.min.split.size* is 0, that of *mapred.max.split.size* is **Long.MAX** and that of *dfs.block.size* is 64MB.
trans-unit.target: Typically, the default value of *mapred.min.split.size* is 0, that of *mapred.max.split.size* is **Long.MAX** and that of *dfs.block.size* is 64MB.

trans-unit.source: As we can see, given the data size, tuning these parameters by "setting" them allows us to tune the number of mappers used.
trans-unit.target: As we can see, given the data size, tuning these parameters by "setting" them allows us to tune the number of mappers used.

trans-unit.source: A few other more **advanced options** for optimizing Hive performance are mentioned below.
trans-unit.target: A few other more **advanced options** for optimizing Hive performance are mentioned below.

trans-unit.source: These allow you to set the memory allocated to map and reduce tasks, and can be useful in tweaking performance.
trans-unit.target: These allow you to set the memory allocated to map and reduce tasks, and can be useful in tweaking performance.

trans-unit.source: Please keep in mind that the *mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb* cannot be greater than the physical memory size of each worker node in the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Please keep in mind that the *mapreduce.reduce.memory.mb* cannot be greater than the physical memory size of each worker node in the Hadoop cluster.
